children.name: surprised and upset because something bad has happened
shocked
children.definition: /ʃɒktǁʃɑːkt/ bị sốc
examples: ▪ I was shocked when I saw the size of the telephone bill.
▪ Everyone seemed really shocked when I told them I’d started smoking.

children.name: shocked (that): bị sốc rằng
examples: ▪ I’m shocked that you’ve let things get this far.

children.name: shocked at: bị sốc bởi
examples: ▪ I was shocked at the change in his appearance.
▪ Gabby was shocked by how unpleasant they were to their mother.

children.name: be shocked to hear/learn/find something etc: bị sốc khi nghe/học/tìm ra cái gì
examples: ▪ We were shocked to hear about Brian’s heart attack - he’s so young.
▪ When I returned, I was shocked to discover that Rod had lost his job.

children.name: deeply shockedvery shocked:cực kì sốc
examples: ▪ We were deeply shocked to hear of the baby’s death.

children.name: horrified
children.definition: /ˈhɒrɪfaɪd, ˈhɒrəfaɪdǁˈhɔː-, ˈhɑː-/  extremely shocked by something very unpleasant or frightening that has happened:bị kinh hoàng
examples: ▪ Horrified passengers saw the man fall under the train.
▪ There was a horrified look on his face.

children.name: horrified by: bị thất kinh bởi
examples: ▪ The Prime Minister issued a statement saying he was ‘shocked and horrified’ by the massacre.

children.name: appalled
children.definition: /əˈpɔːld/  very shocked by something that is very bad or unpleasant:bị làm kinh hoàng, kinh sợ, thất kinh

children.name: appalled by:bị làm kinh hoàng, kinh sợ, thất kinh bởi
examples: ▪ I knew everyone in the room was appalled by my behaviour, but I didn’t care.
▪ Appalled at the state of the kitchen, she set about scrubbing away the layers of grime and grease.

children.name: appalled that:bị làm kinh hoàng, kinh sợ, thất kinh rằng
examples: ▪ We’re absolutely appalled that the newspapers can freely make allegations about this company.

children.name: appalled to hear/see/find out etcbị làm kinh hoàng, kinh sợ, thất kinh khi nghe/thấy/tìm ra
examples: ▪ I was appalled to learn that a serial killer was running a drugs operation in a high-security prison.

children.name: devastated/shattered
children.definition: /ˈdevəsteɪtɪd, ˈdevəsteɪtəd, ˈʃætəʳd/  so shocked and upset by something terrible that has happened that you cannot continue with your life:bị thất kinh
examples: ▪ Without warning, my husband moved out, leaving me so shattered I couldn’t continue.

children.name: devastated/shattered by: bị làm thất kinh bởi
examples: ▪ I went back to my motel, devastated by the news of her death.

children.name: traumatized
children.definition: alsotraumatisedBritish /ˈtrɔːmətaɪzd/  if someone istraumatizedby a bad event or experience, it badly affects the way they behave or react to things for a long time afterwards:bị choáng
examples: ▪ The attack on her in August 1990 had left her traumatized and unable to leave the house.
▪ a frightened, traumatized child
traumatized by: bị choáng bởi
▪ Some students were traumatized by the anatomy classes, while others were unaffected.

children.name: be in a state of shock
children.definition: /biː ɪn ə ˌsteɪt əv ˈʃɒkǁ-ˈʃɑːk/  to feel very shocked by something, so that you cannot do things properly or talk about things clearly for a long time afterwards:bị sốc
examples: ▪ Two days after the earthquake, many people were still in a state of shock.
▪ He arrived at my house in a state of shock, unable to tell me clearly what had happened.

children.name: shaken/shaken up
children.definition: /ˈʃeɪkən, ˌʃeɪkən ˈʌp/ shockedand feeling weak and nervous, because something very unpleasant or frightening has happened:bị kinh hãi
examples: ▪ He was pulled from the wreckage of the car, alive but very shaken.
▪ The fire in the hotel was not very serious but everyone was shaken up by it.

children.name: shaken/shaken up by: bị làm cho kinh hãi bởi
examples: ▪ She was visibly shaken by the severity of her sentence, and left the court in tears.

children.name: badly shaken: cực kì kinh hãi
examples: ▪ She was badly shaken by the attack and found it difficult to describe her ordeal to the police.

children.name: aghast
children.definition: /əˈgɑːstǁəˈgæst/  written very shocked by something that you have just been told or have found out about:kinh hoàng, kinh ngạc
examples: ▪ ‘Ten thousand pounds!’ she said, aghast.
▪ Some of the Republican policies have left feminists dismayed and aghast.

children.name: aghast at: kinh hoàng, kinh ngạc bởi
examples: ▪ Mr Sullivan seemed aghast at the prospect of losing his only daughter to this arrogant young man.

children.name: shock
children.definition: /ʃɒkǁʃɑːk/  the unpleasant feeling of surprise that you have when something bad happens, especially when you do not expect it:
examples: ▪ Fellow students expressed shock and dismay over the racist incidents.

children.name: with shock
examples: ▪ We listened to the announcer with shock and disbelief -- another bomb had exploded in the city.

children.name: horror
children.definition: /ˈhɒrəʳǁˈhɔː-, ˈhɑː-/  a very strong feeling of surprise and disbelief that you have when something very unpleasant or frightening happens:
examples: ▪ It’s hard for me even now to relate my feelings of horror and incredulity about what happened.

children.name: in horror
examples: ▪ She screamed again and stared in horror at what lay in the doorway.

children.name: with horror
examples: ▪ He was trembling with horror and disbelief.

children.name: to my/your/his etc horror
examples: ▪ To my horror, I saw James’ car draw up outside the gate.

children.name: so shocked that you show it in your behaviour or appearance
speechless
children.definition: /ˈspiːtʃləs/  so shocked, angry, upset etc that you cannot speak:không thốt nên lời
examples: ▪ The chairman was speechless when he heard that he had been dismissed.
▪ Almost speechless, her mother managed to gasp out, ‘And how long has this been going on?’
leave somebody speechless: khiến ai không thốt nên lời
▪ Her children’s behaviour is sometimes so bad that it leaves her speechless.
speechlesswith rage/ horror/shock etc: không thốt nên lời vì giận dữ/kinh hoàng/sốc
▪ I didn’t answer. I was speechless with rage.
▪ The little girl seemed speechless with terror.
I’m speechless: tôi thật không thốt nên lời
spoken used to say how shocked or surprised you are
▪ Well, I’m speechless Anna. I really don’t know what to say.

children.name: stunned
children.definition: /stʌnd/  so shocked that you are unable to react immediately:bị kinh hãi
examples: ▪ The news of his brother’s death left him too stunned to speak.
▪ Canada was completely stunned by the shooting, for it thinks of itself as a peaceful, gentle nation.
▪ She looked pale and stunned -- it was clear that something awful had happened.
stunned by: bị kinh hãi bởi
▪ His brother seemed stunned by the verdict.
stunned silence : im lặng vì sửng sốt
when people stop talking, because something shocking has happened
▪ After a stunned silence, Peggy added, ‘And I’m not going to change my mind.’

children.name: dazed
children.definition: /deɪzd/  very shocked and unable to think clearly or do anything to improve the situation:bị làm cho ngơ ngác
examples: ▪ I stumbled from the office, feeling dazed and confused, and not really knowing where I was.
▪ He stood there with a dazed expression on his face watching her pack her bags.

children.name: dazed by: bị làm cho ngơ ngác bởi
examples: ▪ Daphne is in hospital, still dazed by the events of the last ten days.

children.name: gobsmacked
children.definition: /ˈgɒbsmæktǁˈgɑːb-/  British spoken so shocked that you cannot speak for a short time:quá kinh ngạc
examples: ▪ ‘Do you feel surprised by your win?’ ‘Gobsmacked would be closer to the truth.’

children.name: shock
children.definition: /ʃɒkǁʃɑːk/  something very bad or unpleasant that happens to you and that you did not expect:
examples: ▪ ‘The bill came to almost £500.’ ‘That must have been a shock.’
get a shock
▪ Gary got a shock when his ex-girlfriend turned up on his doorstep.
give somebody a shock
▪ It gave me a shock to realize that I had almost died.
with a shock
▪ He realised with a faint shock that it was Lulu, much older but still beautiful.
be in for a shock
used to say someone will be shocked when they discover something
▪ If the FBI thought they could outwit him, they were in for a shock.
a rude shock
British a big and very unpleasant shock
▪ Going on holiday with Ian had been a rude shock -- he’d been argumentative, mean and not at all what she’d expected.

children.name: blow
children.definition: /bləʊ/  an unpleasant event or piece of news that makes you shocked, upset, and disappointed:tin sốc
examples: ▪ Not being allowed to return to her own country was a blow from which she never really recovered.

children.name: blow to: tin sốc đối với
examples: ▪ The Colorado river was closed, a bitter blow to rafters and kayakers who may have to wait seven years for a river use permit.

children.name: deal somebody a blow: đối mặt với tin sốc
examples: ▪ His championship hopes were dealt a savage blow last night when he received a hamstring injury.

children.name: bombshell
children.definition: /ˈbɒmʃelǁˈbɑːm-/  a piece of news which is extremely shocking and bad:tin giật gân
examples: drop a bombshell: nói cho ai biết một tin giật gân
tell people something very shocking or surprising
▪ Then Vanessa dropped the bombshell that she was leaving - and leaving that night.
come as a bombshell: là một tin giật gân
▪ For the board of directors, the news of the crash came as a bombshell.

children.name: rude awakening
children.definition: /ˌruːd əˈweɪkənɪŋ/  a sudden shock that happens when you find out the unpleasant truth about a situation:thức tỉnh
examples: ▪ Moving to the city was a rude awakening for an innocent country girl like Eli.
be in for a rude awakening : làm cho tỉnh ngộ
used to say that someone will be unpleasantly shocked when they discover something
▪ I was expecting the oral exam to be easy, but I was in for a rude awakening.

children.name: shock
children.definition: /ʃɒkǁʃɑːk/  to make someone feel very surprised and upset:bị sốc
examples: ▪ What really shocked me was that no-one seemed to care about all the beggars.

children.name: it shocks somebody to see/realize/hear etc: khiến ai bị sốc khi thấy/nhận ra/nghe
examples: ▪ It shocked us to see how ill she looked.

children.name: shock somebody into doing something: cú sốc khiến cho ai phải làm gì
examples: ▪ I just felt I had to shock her into taking some action.

children.name: shock somebody into something: cú sốc khiến ai như thế nào
examples: ▪ My father was shocked into silence.

children.name: come as a shock (to sb)
children.definition: come as a shock (to somebody)/ˌkʌm əz ə ˈʃɒk (tə somebody ǁ-ˈʃɑːk-/  if something unpleasantcomes as a shock, it makes you feel surprised and upset because you were not expecting it at all:là một cơn sốc đối với ai
examples: ▪ I know this will come as a shock to you Ray, but try to understand how I feel.
▪ The revelations of child abuse at the home have come as a profound shock to parents and social workers.

children.name: stun
children.definition: /stʌn/  if something stuns you, especially a piece of news, it makes you feel so surprised and upset that you cannot speak or do anything immediately afterwards:làm kinh ngạc
examples: ▪ Sasha was too stunned by what had happened to say a word.
▪ His words stunned her, and she stared at him in disbelief.

children.name: knock/throw sb for a loop
children.definition: knock/throw somebody for a loop/ˌnɒk, ˌθrəʊ somebody fər ə ˈluːpǁˌnɑːk-/  American informal if something unexpectedknocks someone fora loop, it shocks or upsets them:làm kinh hoàng ai đó
examples: ▪ Joanna’s resignation really threw me for a loop.

children.name: ▪ His next question totally knocked me for a loop.He said, ‘So what makes you think you’re good enough to get into law school?’
shake sb up
children.definition: shake somebody up/ˌʃeɪk somebody ˈʌp/  if an unpleasant experienceshakessomeoneup,they are shocked and upset by it:làm ai đó bị kinh hãi
examples: ▪ Did that lightning shake you up, honey?
▪ Katherine was one of the fairest people you could ever hope to meet, so her criticism really shook me up.

children.name: rock
children.definition: /rɒkǁrɑːk/  if a piece of news rocks a large group of people or an organization, it shocks them - used especially in news reports:làm ai bị sốc
examples: ▪ The scandal has rocked the banking world.
▪ The law firm was rocked by accusations of bribery and dishonesty.

children.name: shocked
children.definition: /ʃɒktǁʃɑːkt/  surprised, upset, and offended by an event or by someone’s behaviour, when you think it is morally wrong or unfair:bị sốc
examples: ▪ Shocked viewers jammed the switchboard with complaints.
shock[transitive verb]làm sốc ai
▪ The shows are designed deliberately to shock audiences.

children.name: shocked by: bị làm sốc bởi
examples: ▪ I am truly shocked by the content of the program.

children.name: shocked at: bị sốc với
examples: ▪ She was shocked at her own depraved behavior.

children.name: outraged
children.definition: /ˈaʊtreɪdʒd/  very shocked and angry about something you think is morally wrong or unfair:căm phẫn
examples: ▪ We were outraged when we heard the rapist had only got a two year sentence.
▪ His remarks, intended to calm the crisis, only served to alarm the already outraged Black community.
outrage[transitive verb not in progressive]làm cho căm phẫn
▪ His remarks puzzled some people and outraged others.

children.name: outraged at/by: bị làm cho căm phẫn bởi
examples: ▪ My mother was outraged at the idea that she might be kept from seeing her grandchildren.

children.name: scandalized
children.definition: alsoscandalisedBritish /ˈskændl-aɪzd/  very shocked and offended by something that you disapprove of, especially because it is morally wrong - use this especially when a lot of people feel this way:làm xấu
examples: ▪ Their scandalized neighbours began a petition to remove them from the neighbourhood.
scandalizealsoscandaliseBritish [transitive verb not in progressive]làm xấu
▪ She had scandalized her family and embarrassed her husband.

children.name: scandalized by: bị làm xấu bởi
examples: ▪ At first, the public was scandalized by his nude paintings.

children.name: scandalized by: bị làm xấu bởi
examples: ▪ The country was scandalized by the news of the President’s alleged affair.

children.name: outrage
children.definition: /ˈaʊtreɪdʒ/  the strong feeling of being shocked and angry about something such as a public statement or action that you think is morally wrong or unfair:căm phẫn
examples: ▪ The sense of anger and outrage within the community seemed to grow by the hour.
▪ Prominent Republicans have expressed outrage at the decision.
▪ The anarchic music of punk caused public outrage when it first burst upon the scene.

children.name: shocking
children.definition: /ˈʃɒkɪŋǁˈʃɑː-/  making you feel shocked and upset:gây sốc
examples: ▪ These shocking events horrified the entire world.
▪ The report revealed some shocking new facts about the effect of drinking on health.
▪ It can be quite shocking for a child to see the changes in his or her body as puberty approaches.

children.name: devastating/shattering
children.definition: /ˈdevəsteɪtɪŋ, ˈʃætərɪŋ/  extremely shocking and upsetting:làm choáng
examples: ▪ Losing your job can be a psychologically devastating experience.
